title: Tuberculous Meningitis
scope: ** Diagnosis, anti-tuberculous treatment, adjunctive corticosteroids, and monitoring of tuberculous meningitis in adults. Includes BMRC staging, CSF analysis, empiric treatment initiation, RIPE therapy with CNS modifications, management of hydrocephalus, paradoxical reaction/IRIS, and prolonged treatment course monitoring. Excludes pediatric TBM, spinal TB (Pott disease), tuberculomas managed surgically, and HIV-specific ART initiation protocols (though HIV co-infection is addressed).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; anemia common in chronic TB; leukocytosis or leukopenia; lymphopenia in advanced disease
Essential/Core Labs.target: Mild leukocytosis or normal; lymphopenia suggests advanced disease

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline renal/hepatic function BEFORE starting RIPE therapy (isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide all hepatotoxic); electrolytes for SIADH
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; document baseline ALT/AST for hepatotoxicity monitoring

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: CSF:serum glucose ratio is critical for TB meningitis diagnosis (typically <0.5)
Exclude concurrent bacteremia; disseminated TB can be cultured from blood (mycobacterial blood cultures separately)
Before LP; coagulopathy assessment; DIC in severe sepsis
Elevated in active TB; nonspecific but supports infectious/inflammatory process
Inflammatory marker; elevated in active TB; monitor treatment response
SIADH is common complication of TBM (up to 45% of cases); cerebral salt wasting also reported
Low-to-moderate elevation in TB (typically <2); helps distinguish from acute bacterial meningitis where procalcitonin is typically >2
Essential/Core Labs.target: Mildly elevated (<2 ng/mL favors TB over bacterial)

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: HIV co-infection in 50-70% of TBM in endemic areas; affects prognosis, treatment (drug interactions with ART), and IRIS risk
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Document result; if positive: CD4 count, viral load

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Degree of immunosuppression guides prognosis and ART timing
Positive supports TB diagnosis but CANNOT rule out TBM if negative (sensitivity only 50-70% in active TB, lower in immunocompromised); negative IGRA does NOT exclude TBM
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Positive supports diagnosis; negative does NOT rule out TBM

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Same limitations as IGRA; up to 50% false negative in active TBM; immunosuppression further reduces sensitivity
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Positive supports diagnosis; negative does NOT rule out TBM
Document baseline; expect elevation on treatment

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Chronic hepatitis B increases hepatotoxicity risk with RIPE therapy
Chronic hepatitis C increases hepatotoxicity risk with RIPE therapy
Confirm SIADH if hyponatremia present (urine osm >100, urine Na >40 with low serum Na)
Disseminated TB (miliary); especially in HIV co-infection
Adrenal insufficiency from TB (adrenal involvement in disseminated disease); rifampin accelerates cortisol metabolism

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Sputum AFB smear and culture x3 (CPT 87116)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Active pulmonary TB (present in 30-50% of TBM cases); aids in obtaining drug susceptibility
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: AFB positive supports disseminated TB; culture for sensitivities

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Rapid molecular detection of pulmonary TB and rifampin resistance

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Drug susceptibility testing (DST) on positive cultures
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Guide therapy if drug-resistant TB suspected (MDR-TB, XDR-TB)
Culture-negative cases; atypical presentations; when molecular and culture methods fail
Exclude concurrent or alternative fungal meningitis (especially in HIV with CD4 <100)
Neurosarcoidosis in differential (chronic basilar meningitis with cranial neuropathies)
Neurosyphilis in differential for chronic meningitis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in 50-80% of TBM; monitor for hydrocephalus and ICP
Lumbar Puncture.target: Typically 100-300 mm H2O (mildly to moderately elevated); markedly elevated suggests hydrocephalus or mass effect

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Lymphocytic pleocytosis is hallmark of TBM; early disease may show neutrophil predominance transitioning to lymphocytic over days
Lumbar Puncture.target: WBC 100-500 cells/uL (lymphocyte predominant, typically 60-90% lymphocytes); early cases may have neutrophil predominance; very low counts (<50) or very high (>1000) atypical

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Markedly elevated protein is characteristic of TBM (higher than viral, comparable to bacterial)
Lumbar Puncture.target: Elevated 100-500+ mg/dL (often >100; can exceed 500 in advanced cases with subarachnoid block)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Very low CSF glucose is characteristic (CSF:serum ratio <0.5); distinguishes from viral meningitis where glucose is normal
Lumbar Puncture.target: Low: <45 mg/dL or CSF:serum ratio <0.5 (often <0.3); glucose may be extremely low (<20 mg/dL) in advanced cases

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Exclude bacterial meningitis; should be NEGATIVE in TB meningitis
Lumbar Puncture.target: No organisms (Gram stain does not detect mycobacteria)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Low sensitivity (10-20%) but highly specific if positive; larger CSF volume (>6 mL) and prolonged microscopy improve yield
Lumbar Puncture.target: AFB detected; negative does NOT rule out TBM (sensitivity only 10-20% on standard smear)

Lumbar Puncture.item: CSF TB culture (Lowenstein-Jensen and liquid BACTEC) (CPT 87116)
Lumbar Puncture.rationale: GOLD STANDARD for diagnosis; sensitivity 50-80% but takes 2-6 weeks for growth; ALWAYS send regardless of smear result
Lumbar Puncture.target: Mycobacterium tuberculosis growth; provides drug susceptibility testing

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Rapid molecular PCR — sensitivity 60-80% for TBM (lower than pulmonary TB); specificity >98%; also detects rifampin resistance; results in 2 hours
Lumbar Puncture.target: M. tuberculosis detected; rifampin susceptible; negative does NOT rule out TBM

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated ADA supports TB diagnosis; >8-10 U/L suggests TBM; sensitivity 70-90%, specificity 80-90%; less specific in HIV co-infection
Lumbar Puncture.target: Elevated: >8-10 U/L strongly supports TBM (some use cutoff >6 U/L); very high levels (>20) highly suggestive

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in TBM (>3.5 mmol/L); helps distinguish from viral meningitis
Rapid exclusion of common bacterial and viral pathogens; does NOT detect M. tuberculosis
Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative for other pathogens (positive for another pathogen suggests alternative diagnosis)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Exclude cryptococcal meningitis (especially HIV co-infection, similar CSF profile)
Exclude leptomeningeal carcinomatosis (chronic meningitis with low glucose)
Intrathecal antibody production; may be positive in TBM but nonspecific
Repeat LP at 2-4 weeks if initial cultures negative but clinical suspicion remains high; larger volume (20+ mL) improves yield

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate — before LP to exclude mass effect, hydrocephalus
Essential/First-line.target: Hydrocephalus (present in 60-80% of TBM); basilar enhancement; tuberculomas; cerebral edema; infarcts (especially in basal ganglia and internal capsule territory)
Miliary pattern (up to 30-50%); upper lobe infiltrates; hilar/mediastinal lymphadenopathy; pleural effusion; may be NORMAL in isolated CNS TB

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24-48h; STAT if available and clinical deterioration
Essential/First-line.target: Basilar meningeal enhancement (most characteristic finding); hydrocephalus; tuberculomas (ring-enhancing lesions); periventricular infarcts (vasculitis of perforating arteries); cranial nerve enhancement; spinal cord involvement

Extended.target: Basilar meningeal enhancement; hydrocephalus; ring-enhancing tuberculomas; infarcts
Narrowing or occlusion of basal arteries (especially middle cerebral artery branches, lenticulostriate arteries); TB vasculitis

Extended.timing: If spinal symptoms present (radiculopathy, myelopathy, bladder dysfunction)
Extended.target: Spinal arachnoiditis; spinal tuberculomas; epidural abscess; cord compression

Extended.timing: If chest X-ray abnormal or high suspicion for pulmonary/miliary TB
Extended.target: Miliary nodules; tree-in-bud pattern; lymphadenopathy; cavitary disease

Extended.timing: If altered consciousness with suspected seizures
Extended.target: Seizure activity, non-convulsive status epilepticus, focal slowing
Baseline; QTc assessment (fluoroquinolones can prolong QTc if used); electrolyte abnormalities

Rare/Specialized.timing: If venous sinus thrombosis suspected (worsening headache, papilledema, seizures)
If vasculitis suspected and MRA inconclusive
If disseminated TB suspected (hepatosplenic, adrenal, peritoneal)
Rare/Specialized.target: Hepatosplenic granulomas; adrenal enlargement; peritoneal thickening; lymphadenopathy

Rare/Specialized.timing: If clinical signs of elevated ICP; declining GCS despite treatment

Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.indication: First-line anti-TB therapy; excellent CNS penetration (CSF levels 80-90% of serum); bactericidal against M. tuberculosis

dosing.instructions: 5 mg/kg PO/IV daily (max 300 mg/day); some experts use 10 mg/kg for first 2 months for enhanced CNS penetration; duration 12 months

Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.contraindications: Acute hepatic disease; severe hepatic impairment; prior INH hepatotoxicity; caution with alcohol use
Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.monitoring: LFTs (ALT/AST) at baseline, 2 weeks, then monthly; hold if ALT >5x ULN (asymptomatic) or >3x ULN with symptoms

Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.indication: First-line anti-TB therapy; bactericidal; moderate CNS penetration (10-20% of serum in inflamed meninges); critical for sterilizing activity

dosing.instructions: 10 mg/kg PO/IV daily (max 600 mg/day); some experts recommend 15 mg/kg (max 900 mg) for TBM due to lower CNS penetration; take on empty stomach; IV formulation available for patients unable to take PO

Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.contraindications: Severe hepatic disease; concurrent protease inhibitors (major drug interactions); porphyria
Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.monitoring: LFTs at baseline, 2 weeks, monthly; CBC monthly (rare thrombocytopenia); orange discoloration of bodily fluids (warn patient); EXTENSIVE drug interactions (warfarin, OCPs, antiretrovirals, steroids)

Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.indication: First-line anti-TB therapy; excellent CNS penetration; most effective sterilizing agent in first 2 months; bactericidal at acidic pH (in caseous granulomas)

dosing.instructions: 25 mg/kg PO daily (max 2000 mg/day); round to nearest 250 mg; duration: 2 months (intensive phase only)

Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.contraindications: Severe hepatic disease; acute gout (causes hyperuricemia); porphyria
Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.monitoring: LFTs at baseline, 2 weeks, monthly during PZA use; uric acid (expect elevation — treat only symptomatic gout); joint pain assessment

Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.indication: First-line anti-TB therapy; bacteriostatic; included to prevent emergence of drug resistance during intensive phase; POOR CNS penetration

dosing.instructions: 15-20 mg/kg PO daily (max 1600 mg/day); duration: 2 months (intensive phase); some experts substitute ethionamide (better CNS penetration) for TBM

Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.contraindications: Optic neuritis (pre-existing); renal impairment (dose adjust, renally cleared); visual impairment that prevents acuity monitoring
Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.monitoring: Visual acuity and color vision (Ishihara plates) at baseline, then monthly; discontinue IMMEDIATELY if visual symptoms develop (optic neuritis); renal function for dose adjustment

Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.indication: Prevention of isoniazid-induced peripheral neuropathy; ALWAYS co-prescribe with INH

dosing.instructions: 25-50 mg PO daily throughout INH therapy; use 50 mg daily if HIV co-infection, diabetes, alcoholism, malnutrition, or pre-existing neuropathy

Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.indication: Adjunctive corticosteroid for ALL BMRC stages — reduces mortality by 30% (NNT ~5 for stage II/III); reduces inflammation, cerebral edema, and vasculitis

doseOptions.text: See Appendix A for detailed Thwaites protocol
doseOptions.orderSentence: Dexamethasone (Thwaites protocol) See Appendix A for detailed Thwaites protocol IV

dosing.instructions: BMRC Stage I: 0.3 mg/kg/day IV x 4 weeks, then taper PO over 4 weeks. BMRC Stage II-III: 0.4 mg/kg/day IV x 4 weeks, then taper PO over 4 weeks. Total steroid duration: 6-8 weeks. Start simultaneously with anti-TB therapy
dosing.orderSentence: Dexamethasone (Thwaites protocol) See Appendix A for detailed Thwaites protocol IV

Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.contraindications: Active GI bleeding (relative); uncontrolled diabetes (relative — manage glucose aggressively); concurrent untreated strongyloides (dissemination risk — screen in endemic areas)
Acute/Emergent — Anti-Tuberculous Therap.monitoring: Glucose q6h while on IV steroids; blood pressure; GI prophylaxis; mood/psychiatric effects; infection surveillance; taper slowly (do NOT stop abruptly)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Fever reduction and headache; avoid NSAIDs due to hepatotoxicity risk with RIPE therapy

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 3g/day (reduced from 4g due to concurrent hepatotoxic medications)

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic disease; concurrent RIPE therapy warrants reduced max dose (3g/day)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Seizure management (seizures occur in 20-30% of TBM); preferred ASM due to minimal hepatic metabolism (important with hepatotoxic RIPE therapy)

dosing.instructions: 1000-1500 mg IV load; then 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID; max 3000 mg/day; preferred over phenytoin because no significant hepatic metabolism or CYP interactions with RIPE

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust for CrCl <50)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Renal function; behavioral side effects (irritability, depression)

dosing.instructions: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg) over 2 min; may repeat x1 in 5 min

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Respiratory status; SpO2; airway equipment ready

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nausea/vomiting (common with RIPE therapy, especially pyrazinamide)

dosing.instructions: 4 mg IV/PO q6h PRN

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: GI prophylaxis (steroids + critical illness); gastroprotection during RIPE therapy

dosing.instructions: 40 mg IV/PO daily

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Elevated ICP / cerebral edema management (before definitive hydrocephalus treatment)

dosing.instructions: 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus; then 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h; maintain serum osm <320

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Serum osmolality (<320); electrolytes; renal function; I/O

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Acute herniation from hydrocephalus or cerebral edema

dosing.instructions: 30 mL IV via central line over 10-20 min for acute herniation
40 mg SC daily; start when no active hemorrhagic complications and platelet count adequate

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Active bleeding; thrombocytopenia (platelets <50K); hemorrhagic transformation on imaging
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Platelets q3 days; signs of bleeding

dosing.instructions: Apply bilaterally on admission

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: SIADH management (if Na <130 with confirmed SIADH)

dosing.instructions: 1-1.2 L/day fluid restriction

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Na q6-8h; urine osm and Na; I/O

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Alternative to ethambutol for CNS TB (BETTER CNS penetration than EMB); used when drug resistance suspected or EMB toxicity

dosing.instructions: 15-20 mg/kg PO daily (max 1000 mg); often in divided BID dosing to reduce GI side effects; frequently used in place of EMB for TBM due to superior CNS penetration

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Severe hepatic disease (hepatotoxic — additive with INH/RIF); pregnancy (teratogenic)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: LFTs monthly; TSH q3 months (causes hypothyroidism in up to 30%); GI tolerance

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Drug-resistant TB (MDR-TB); rifampin-resistant TB detected on GeneXpert; alternative when first-line agents not tolerated; good CNS penetration

dosing.instructions: 750-1000 mg PO/IV daily; superior CNS penetration among fluoroquinolones; critical component of MDR-TB regimen

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: QT prolongation; tendinopathy; myasthenia gravis (worsens weakness); pregnancy
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: QTc; tendon symptoms; renal function; glucose (dysglycemia); C. diff

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Drug-resistant TB; alternative fluoroquinolone with excellent CNS penetration; useful in MDR-TB meningitis regimens

dosing.instructions: 400 mg PO/IV daily; excellent CNS penetration; some studies suggest benefit even in drug-susceptible TBM (moxifloxacin-containing regimens)

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: QT prolongation (more than levofloxacin); hepatic disease

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Drug-resistant TB (MDR/XDR-TB); excellent CNS penetration; reserve for resistant cases due to toxicity

dosing.instructions: 600 mg PO/IV daily (some protocols use 600 mg BID initially then reduce to daily); duration limited by toxicity (aim for <6 months if possible)

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Concurrent serotonergic medications (serotonin syndrome); thrombocytopenia; myelosuppression
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: CBC weekly x 4, then monthly; peripheral neuropathy assessment monthly; visual acuity (optic neuropathy); lactic acidosis symptoms

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Drug-resistant TB (MDR-TB); injectable agent for severe MDR-TBM; second-line injectable

dosing.instructions: 15 mg/kg IV/IM daily (max 1000 mg); adjust for renal function; duration typically 2-4 months

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Renal impairment; hearing impairment; vestibular dysfunction; pregnancy (ototoxic to fetus)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Audiometry monthly; renal function weekly; drug levels; vestibular function

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Drug-resistant TB (MDR/XDR-TB); CNS penetration adequate; frequent neuropsychiatric side effects

dosing.instructions: 250 mg PO BID initially, increase to 500 mg BID; max 1000 mg/day; take with pyridoxine 50-100 mg daily

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Seizure disorder (lowers seizure threshold); severe depression; psychosis; renal impairment
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Psychiatric symptoms (depression, psychosis, suicidality); seizures; renal function; pyridoxine supplementation mandatory

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Communicating hydrocephalus not responsive to medical management or serial LPs; definitive treatment for persistent hydrocephalus

dosing.instructions: Neurosurgical procedure; discuss timing with neurosurgery (some operate early, others wait for treatment response)

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Post-operative neuro checks; shunt function assessment; infection monitoring

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Acute obstructive hydrocephalus; emergency ICP management; temporizing measure before VP shunt

dosing.instructions: Neurosurgical procedure; bedside in ICU

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: ICP continuous; CSF output and character; daily CSF sampling; ventriculitis surveillance

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Paradoxical worsening (expanding tuberculomas, worsening symptoms) despite adequate anti-TB therapy; TB-IRIS in HIV patients starting ART

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily x 3-5 days; followed by oral prednisone taper over 4-8 weeks; for severe paradoxical reaction or IRIS not responding to dexamethasone taper adjustment

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Glucose; blood pressure; infection surveillance; neuroimaging response

Continuation Phase and Long-Term Treatme.indication: Continuation phase anti-TB therapy; months 3-12 of treatment

doseOptions.orderSentence: Isoniazid (continuation phase) 5 mg/kg daily (max 300 mg) PO

dosing.instructions: 5 mg/kg PO daily (max 300 mg/day); continue for total duration 12 months; some experts recommend 18 months for severe disease or slow responders
dosing.orderSentence: Isoniazid (continuation phase) 5 mg/kg daily (max 300 mg) PO

Continuation Phase and Long-Term Treatme.pretreatment: Documented hepatic function baseline; LFTs stable on treatment
Continuation Phase and Long-Term Treatme.contraindications: Severe hepatic disease; prior INH hepatotoxicity
Continuation Phase and Long-Term Treatme.monitoring: LFTs monthly; peripheral neuropathy assessment; ensure pyridoxine co-administration

Continuation Phase and Long-Term Treatme.indication: Continuation phase anti-TB therapy; months 3-12 of treatment

doseOptions.orderSentence: Rifampin (continuation phase) 10 mg/kg daily (max 600 mg) PO

dosing.instructions: 10 mg/kg PO daily (max 600 mg/day); continue for total 12 months; drug interactions must be reviewed at each visit
dosing.orderSentence: Rifampin (continuation phase) 10 mg/kg daily (max 600 mg) PO

Continuation Phase and Long-Term Treatme.pretreatment: Documented hepatic function baseline; drug interaction review
Continuation Phase and Long-Term Treatme.contraindications: Severe hepatic disease; incompatible drug interactions
Continuation Phase and Long-Term Treatme.monitoring: LFTs monthly; CBC q3 months; drug interaction review at each visit; compliance assessment

doseOptions.orderSentence: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6 — continuation) 25-50 mg daily PO

dosing.instructions: 25-50 mg PO daily for duration of INH therapy
dosing.orderSentence: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6 — continuation) 25-50 mg daily PO

Continuation Phase and Long-Term Treatme.monitoring: Clinical neuropathy assessment at each visit

Referrals & Consults.item: Infectious disease consultation for anti-TB regimen optimization, drug resistance management, drug interactions (especially with HIV ART), and treatment duration decisions
Neurology consultation for seizure management, altered consciousness evaluation, cranial nerve palsy assessment, and vasculitis monitoring
Neurosurgery consultation for hydrocephalus management (EVD placement, VP shunt evaluation), ICP monitoring, and tuberculoma with mass effect
Critical care/ICU team for BMRC Stage II-III patients, respiratory failure, ICP management, and hemodynamic instability
Ophthalmology for baseline visual acuity and color vision assessment before ethambutol initiation, and for optic neuritis evaluation if visual symptoms develop on treatment
Pulmonology for concurrent pulmonary TB management, miliary TB, and respiratory compromise
HIV specialist/infectious disease for ART initiation timing in co-infected patients (defer ART 2-8 weeks after starting anti-TB therapy to reduce IRIS risk)
Physical therapy for early mobilization, deconditioning prevention, and gait/balance training given prolonged hospitalization
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive rehabilitation, and adaptive equipment if focal deficits persist
Speech-language pathology for swallowing assessment (if altered consciousness or cranial nerve palsies affect CN IX/X) and cognitive-communication evaluation
Social work for treatment adherence support, discharge planning, directly observed therapy (DOT) coordination, and community resources
Public health department notification for TB reporting (mandatory), contact tracing, DOT program enrollment, and treatment completion monitoring
Psychiatry for depression/anxiety screening (chronic illness, social isolation), steroid-induced psychiatric effects, and cycloserine-induced neuropsychiatric symptoms
Audiology for hearing assessment if aminoglycosides used (amikacin)

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if worsening headache, new confusion, seizure, vision changes, worsening weakness, or fever recurrence (may indicate treatment failure, hydrocephalus, or paradoxical reaction)
Take all anti-TB medications together at the same time daily, on an empty stomach (1 hour before or 2 hours after meals) for optimal absorption
Do NOT stop medications early even if feeling better; incomplete treatment leads to relapse and drug resistance; total treatment duration is 12 months minimum
Report immediately: nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice (yellow skin/eyes), dark urine — these may indicate hepatotoxicity requiring medication adjustment
Report any vision changes (blurred vision, difficulty distinguishing colors) immediately — ethambutol can cause optic neuritis (reversible if caught early)
Report numbness, tingling, or burning in hands/feet (peripheral neuropathy) — dose adjustment of INH or increased pyridoxine may be needed
Rifampin causes orange-red discoloration of urine, tears, sweat, and saliva — this is expected and harmless; warn about permanent staining of contact lenses and clothing
Avoid alcohol completely during treatment (increases hepatotoxicity risk with INH, RIF, and PZA)
Rifampin reduces effectiveness of oral contraceptives — use alternative contraception methods during treatment and for 1 month after completion
Directly Observed Therapy (DOT) will be arranged through the public health department to ensure treatment completion and monitor for side effects
Follow-up with neurology in 2-4 weeks after discharge, then monthly for first 3 months, then every 2-3 months until treatment completion
Follow-up with infectious disease at 2 weeks, then monthly during intensive phase, and every 1-2 months during continuation phase
Driving restrictions if seizures occurred — do not drive until seizure-free per state law (typically 3-12 months) and cleared by neurology

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Absolute alcohol avoidance for entire 12-month treatment duration to minimize hepatotoxicity risk from RIPE therapy
Contact tracing and screening for household contacts and close contacts (public health department coordinates; focus on pulmonary TB transmission)
Respiratory isolation precautions if concurrent pulmonary TB confirmed or suspected (airborne precautions, N95 respirator for healthcare workers, negative pressure room)
Nutritional support and high-protein diet to support immune recovery (malnutrition common in TB patients and worsens outcomes)
Adequate hydration throughout treatment to reduce medication-related GI side effects and maintain renal function
Smoking cessation to improve immune function and reduce respiratory complications
Mental health support for chronic illness burden, social stigma, prolonged treatment course, and medication side effects
Seizure safety precautions if seizures occurred: avoid heights, swimming alone, operating heavy machinery; ensure home safety evaluation
Medication adherence support: pill organizers, DOT enrollment, family education, and addressing barriers to adherence (transportation, cost, side effects)

differential.features: Acute onset (hours-days, not weeks); higher fever; CSF neutrophilic pleocytosis with very low glucose; positive Gram stain (60-90%); rapid deterioration
differential.tests: CSF Gram stain and culture; BioFire ME panel; procalcitonin markedly elevated (>2); CSF lactate elevated; rapid response to antibiotics

differential.features: Subacute/chronic; immunocompromised (HIV CD4 <100); headache predominant; minimal pleocytosis; CSF India ink positive; often less focal than TBM
differential.tests: CSF cryptococcal antigen (CrAg — very sensitive); India ink; fungal culture; serum CrAg; opening pressure often very high

differential.features: Acute onset; self-limited; CSF lymphocytic but normal glucose and mildly elevated protein; less severe clinical course; no basilar enhancement
differential.tests: CSF enterovirus PCR; BioFire ME panel; normal glucose distinguishes from TBM; MRI normal

differential.features: Chronic meningitis; psychiatric symptoms; pupillary abnormalities (Argyll Robertson pupils); tabes dorsalis; history of STI; CSF may mimic TBM
differential.tests: CSF VDRL (specific); serum RPR/VDRL and FTA-ABS; response to penicillin

differential.features: Known malignancy; multiple cranial neuropathies; progressive; CSF low glucose and high protein (mimics TBM); positive cytology
differential.tests: CSF cytology (repeat x3 for sensitivity); MRI with contrast (leptomeningeal enhancement); flow cytometry

differential.features: Chronic basilar meningitis; cranial nerve palsies (especially CN VII); hilar lymphadenopathy; elevated ACE; non-caseating granulomas
differential.tests: Serum and CSF ACE; chest CT (bilateral hilar adenopathy); biopsy (non-caseating granulomas vs caseating in TB); IGRA/PPD negative

differential.features: Geographic exposure (Ohio/Mississippi Valley, Southwest US); chronic meningitis; CSF similar to TBM; endemic mycosis
differential.tests: Histoplasma/Coccidioides antibodies and antigen (serum and CSF); fungal cultures; complement fixation titers

differential.features: Subacute; may have systemic autoimmune features; steroid-responsive; cranial neuropathies; no fever initially
differential.tests: Autoimmune panel; IgG4 levels; meningeal biopsy; response to immunotherapy; no organisms on culture

differential.features: Prior antibiotic use; CSF may show lymphocytic shift and negative cultures mimicking TBM
differential.tests: Antibiotic history; BioFire ME panel (detects DNA even after antibiotics); procalcitonin; clinical trajectory

differential.features: Immunocompromised (HIV); progressive focal deficits; periventricular enhancing lesions; EBV PCR positive in CSF
differential.tests: MRI with contrast; CSF EBV PCR; CSF cytology and flow cytometry; stereotactic biopsy

differential.features: Focal deficits; ring-enhancing lesion with restricted diffusion; fever and headache; may coexist with TBM (tuberculous abscess)
differential.tests: MRI with contrast and DWI (ring enhancement with central restriction); neurosurgical aspiration; cultures

evidence.recommendation: Adjunctive dexamethasone reduces mortality in TBM (all BMRC stages)
evidence.source: [Thwaites et al. (NEJM 2004)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17041976/) — RCT of 545 patients; 30% mortality reduction with dexamethasone

evidence.recommendation: RIPE therapy (INH, RIF, PZA, EMB) as standard initial regimen
evidence.source: [WHO consolidated guidelines on tuberculosis (2022)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35536703/); ATS/CDC/IDSA Treatment of TB ([Nahid et al. CID 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27516382/))
[WHO guidelines (2022)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35536703/); ATS/CDC/IDSA guidelines; AAP Red Book; [Donald PR. Tuberculosis 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20810322/)

evidence.recommendation: GeneXpert MTB/RIF on CSF for rapid molecular diagnosis
evidence.source: Bahr et al. (Lancet Infect Dis 2018) — systematic review; sensitivity ~60-80% on CSF; [Nhu et al. (Lancet Infect Dis 2014)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25038137/)

evidence.recommendation: CSF adenosine deaminase (ADA) >8-10 U/L supports TBM diagnosis
evidence.source: Xu et al. (PLoS One 2014) — meta-analysis of diagnostic accuracy; [Tuon et al. (Scand J Infect Dis 2010)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20001225/)

British Medical Research Council (1948) original classification; validated in multiple cohorts; [Marais et al. (Lancet Infect Dis 2011)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23193880/) uniform case definition
[Rajshekhar V. (Neurol India 2009); hydrocephalus present in 60-80% of TBM; EVD for acute obstruction; VP shunt for communicating hydrocephalus](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19770534/)

evidence.recommendation: Higher-dose rifampin (15 mg/kg) may improve outcomes in TBM
evidence.source: [Ruslami et al. (Lancet Infect Dis 2013)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23809224/) — pharmacokinetic study; Te Brake et al. (Clin Infect Dis 2015); adequate CSF levels may require higher doses
WHO MDR-TB guidelines; Thwaites et al. (CID 2011) review; good CNS penetration documented
Meintjes et al. (NEJM 2018) — prednisone for TB-IRIS; Singh et al. (BMC Infect Dis 2016) — paradoxical reactions in TBM

evidence.recommendation: Levetiracetam preferred ASM in TBM (minimal hepatic metabolism, no CYP interactions)
evidence.source: Expert consensus; avoids hepatic enzyme interactions with RIPE; Zhu et al. (Epilepsy Res 2017)

evidence.recommendation: Ethionamide as alternative to EMB for improved CNS penetration
evidence.source: [Donald PR. (Tuberculosis 2010)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20810322/); superior CSF penetration compared to ethambutol
[WHO consolidated guidelines (2022)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35536703/); excellent CNS penetration; Sun et al. (Int J Infect Dis 2019)
[Thwaites et al. (Lancet 2009)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19925964/) — review; larger volume (>6 mL) improves yield

evidence.recommendation: Dexamethasone long-term follow-up shows sustained mortality benefit at 5 years
evidence.source: [Thwaites et al. (NEJM 2004)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17041976/); Torok et al. (PLoS One 2011) — 5-year follow-up

evidence.recommendation: Defer ART 2-8 weeks after starting anti-TB therapy in HIV-TBM co-infection
evidence.source: Torok et al. (NEJM 2011) — immediate vs deferred ART in TBM; immediate ART associated with more severe adverse events without mortality benefit

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (GCS, cranial nerves, motor, meningismus)
monitoring.frequency: q2h x 48h, then q4h; more frequent if declining
monitoring.action: If declining: STAT CT (hydrocephalus?); neurosurgery consult; ICP assessment
If persistent fever >2 weeks: reassess diagnosis; evaluate for drug resistance; consider paradoxical reaction; drug fever

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; 2 weeks; then monthly throughout treatment
monitoring.action: If ALT >5x ULN (asymptomatic) or >3x ULN with symptoms (nausea, vomiting, jaundice): HOLD all hepatotoxic drugs (INH, RIF, PZA); reintroduce one at a time after LFTs normalize; see Appendix B

monitoring.frequency: Baseline before EMB; monthly during EMB use
monitoring.action: If any visual decline: STOP ethambutol immediately; ophthalmology referral STAT; optic neuritis usually reversible if caught early

monitoring.frequency: q6-8h x 48h, then daily, then q visit (OPD)
monitoring.action: If <130: SIADH evaluation and fluid restriction; if <120: 3% saline; balance with adequate hydration
Dose adjust ethambutol and aminoglycosides for renal impairment; evaluate dehydration

monitoring.frequency: q6h during IV dexamethasone; daily after transition to PO; at each visit OPD
monitoring.action: Sliding scale insulin; basal insulin if persistent; monitor closely in diabetic patients
If symptomatic gout: colchicine 0.6 mg BID; dose reduce PZA or discontinue if severe; do NOT stop PZA for asymptomatic hyperuricemia alone
If thrombocytopenia: evaluate rifampin hypersensitivity; if anemia: evaluate chronic disease, drug effect; if neutropenia: evaluate drug effect
SIADH: fluid restriction; cerebral salt wasting: volume repletion with saline

monitoring.frequency: At 2-3 months; at treatment completion; and if clinical worsening
monitoring.action: If worsening despite treatment: paradoxical reaction vs treatment failure vs drug resistance; consider repeat LP; ID and neurosurgery input

monitoring.frequency: At 1-2 months if clinical concern; at treatment completion if indicated
monitoring.action: If CSF not improving at 2 months: evaluate for drug resistance; adherence assessment; consider alternative diagnosis; extend treatment duration

monitoring.frequency: Each clinic visit; DOT records review
monitoring.action: If non-adherent: reinforce education; address barriers; intensify DOT; social work involvement; consider directly observed therapy video (VDOT)

monitoring.frequency: Clinical observation continuously; EEG if seizures suspected
monitoring.action: If seizures: optimize levetiracetam; add second agent if needed; cEEG if altered consciousness; avoid hepatically cleared ASMs when possible
Tiered ICP management: CSF drainage, osmotherapy, sedation, neurosurgery

disposition.criteria: Never discharge from ED with suspected TBM — always admit. Discharge from hospital when: clinically improving (resolving fever, improving neuro exam); tolerating oral RIPE therapy; stable or improving imaging; DOT arranged through public health; reliable follow-up with ID and neurology confirmed; able to care for self or adequate home support; no active hydrocephalus requiring intervention
BMRC Stage I (GCS 15, no focal deficits); hemodynamically stable; no seizures; able to cooperate with neuro checks

BMRC Stage II-III (GCS <15 with focal deficits or altered consciousness); active seizures or status epilepticus; hydrocephalus requiring EVD; respiratory compromise; hemodynamic instability; need for continuous EEG; ICP monitoring

Need for neurosurgery (EVD, VP shunt) not available at current facility; need for neuro-ICU expertise; continuous EEG monitoring not available; drug-resistant TB requiring specialized treatment center

Persistent focal neurologic deficits (hemiparesis, cranial neuropathies); cognitive impairment; able to participate in 3h/day therapy; stable on oral RIPE therapy; DOT coordination with rehab facility
Unable to tolerate intensive rehabilitation; requires ongoing nursing care; needs IV medication access or complex wound care; DOT coordination with facility
